div1.head: 51st New York Veterans

p.hi: One of the many old campaign regiments of our army—Roanoke, Newbern, Bull Run, Chantilly, South Mountain, Antietam, Fredericksburgh, Vicksburgh, Jackson, Wilderness, Spottsylvania Coal Harbor & Petersburgh

div1.p: Our army is rapidly accumulating its traditions, its grand remembrances, around which the regiments or larger aggregates, can rally. The regiment above named must not be left in its honorable misfortune, (it was lately cut off & captured, nearly entire, west of Petersburgh, while bravely fighting) without some memento at our hands. It will show to the myriads at home who know of nothing but peaceful scenes, somewhat of the life their brethren our war-worn soldiers really undergo. Moreover the record & prestige of this regiment, & of many others, will be hints of that invicible Union army, full of coolness & pride ,& hardened as fine steel, which we are forming or rather have formed.

The public outside of New York & Brooklyn have lately seen in the correspondence from near Pealtersburgh a casual line or so regarding the 51st veterans & within the last week or so, more detailed notices of their capture. But their career as soldiers has been too marked a one, & must be run over from the beginning.

The 51st New York Volunteers are a part of the 2d division of the 9th Corps. They were recruited in this city & Brooklyn in the summer of 1861, & were known as the Shephard rifles, (from Elliot F. Shephard of this city a valued friend of the regiment,) & started from here in October '61, under Colonel, now General, Ferrero, as part of BurnsidesBurnside's North Carolina expedition. After a danerousdangerous sea-voyage, they were first under fire at the battle of Roanoke, February 1862,fought with coolness & spirit well from the first, & the next month werein the battle of Newbern; in these engagements losing in killed & wounded 12 officers & 150 men. (The regiment has always lost heavily in officers.)

Ordered north in July, the regiment, (space forbids our minutely following their history or movements,) took active part second Bull Run. In the battle of the second day, August 30th, the 51st rendered

div1.head: Mention that the govt is not in fault
div1.ab: mention that the govt is not in fault, is anxious always about the wounded, & liberal in their behalf
Case of Catholic priest, & altar &c at side of dying Irish boy.

middle aged women, & mothers of families, for best, not young women, I & I am compelled to say neither young ladies, have however educated & benevolent, nor the Catholic sisters of charity, Mothers, b however illiterate, bringing thoughts of home, & the magnetic touch of hands, & are very sweet—Mrs Wright & the coarse Irish woman
itemize—that my visits are as an independent missionary on my own hook & in my own style—not as agent of any of the commissions

carry haversack—(list of articles given
–boxes of oranges
once I gave a great ice-cream treat

my note books— some thirty of them—full of names, items, pencil marks half-illegible memoranda—a curious collection—perhaps a thousand names many with h facts of wounds, death, &c home addresses—others with special articles wanted—

mention that I give the money, because many of the wounded men come up from the field wounded dead broke & while they wait for pay day, descriptive lists &c, they remain penniless. Of course every one
